result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Jaimie Lynn Lopez

records.addlTxt:
9:18 AM Defendant Jaimie Lynn Lopez in court.  Attorney David V. Meany appeared by video for State of Wisconsin.  Def is still planning on hiring attorney, got a job last week.  Planning on filling out court appointed form, or PD office if qualifies.  Def going to PD office today.
Adjourned initial appearance scheduled for November 14, 2022 at 09:00 am.
Adjourned initial appearance on November 14, 2022 at 09:00 am.

11:19 AM Defendant Jaimie Lynn Lopez in court.  Attorney David V. Meany appeared by video for State of Wisconsin.  Def provided copy of complaint.  Def plan to hire attorney.
Adjourned initial appearance scheduled for October 24, 2022 at 09:00 am.
Adjourned initial appearance on October 24, 2022 at 09:00 am.

Def shall not possess or consume any mind-altering substances meaning alcoholic beverages, controlled substances, inhalants, synthetic marijuana, or similar substances and/or over the counter medications used contrary to label instructions, or prescription medications not taken in compliance with a prescription issued to the defendant.  Def is not to go into any place where mind altering substances are present, maintained, sold or consumed, except defendant may enter a convenience store or grocery store, even if alcohol is sold there. 
Def to have NO Contact w/ J.P.
